assessment_steps.extracted_paper_info: The paper establishes that mutations in DJ-1 cause autosomal recessive PD with early to mid age of onset, and these may contribute to 1-2% of early onset PD cases. DJ-1 encodes a 189 amino acid protein which is a member of the ThiJ/PfPI superfamily based on its structure. It is expressed in both neurons and astrocytes in the brain, but it is also expressed in many other organs.

functional_evidence_assessment.overall_conclusion: The E163K mutation impairs the ability of DJ-1 to protect against oxidative stress while demonstrating a reduced redistribution towards mitochondria, but retains the ability to mitigate toxicity due to mitochondrial stress and proteasomal impairment. These findings, combined with the established role of DJ-1 in PD pathogenesis and the specific effects observed for this variant, strongly support a pathogenic designation.
